awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Historical Memory, Temporality, and Cultural Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
The management of social differences within and across human collectives has posed unique challenges for policymaking and civic participation. Socially constructed ideas about difference continue to exert a powerful influence on how individuals interact. However, although social scientists and historians have connected notions of alterity to events and processes in the historical past, few empirical studies have paid attention to how everyday actors themselves participate in making links between identity and history over the course of daily social life. Accordingly, this research project asks how the ordinary experience of temporal change or continuity shape ideas about cultural and national identity, and how these shifting notions of individual and collective identity in turn impact the cultural significance of historical narratives. This project, which trains a student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, conducts a case study of informal economic site. 

Doctoral student Jesus Gutierrez, supervised by Charles Briggs at the University of California-Berkeley, will explore how notions of social difference are mediated by conceptions of temporality, memory, and history. The research will take place in southern Brazil, an ideal site as this is a context where ideas about race have been pronounced in informing public attitudes toward national belonging and local history. As a case study, the research will be focused around a network of artists who work across a variety of popular and outsider art forms in the city of Porto Alegre. Through research methods that include participant observation, media and document analysis, network mapping, and ethnographic interviews, the researcher will examine both the significance of race and the emergence of historical elements in each artist's craft and social life. Through extended ethnographic engagement with proximate audiences, customers and government officials, he will determine how the circulation of artworks and performances participates in shifting perceptions of racial and national identity that reach far beyond the individual and the local. Findings from this research will advance scientific and popular understandings of the relationship between history, race and national identity, and it will contribute to the production of more precise theories about the historical and socio-political significance of folk art forms around the globe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals for this research were to understand how historical narratives are mobilized, circulated, encoded or disputed in popular and folkloric art forms in Brazil, and how these art forms therefore play a role in the construction and negotiation of cultural identities at local, regional, national and international scales. In Brazil, the notion of "race" plays a powerful role in the mediation of national identity and historical consciousness, particularly because millions of enslaved Africans were forcibly relocated there from the 16th to the 19th centuries. Today, the legacy of slavery is palpable in all aspects of Brazilian society, and particularly in the multitude of vibrant expressive cultures and art forms that exist in all regions of the country. Whereas understandings of African heritage play a central role in some Brazilian cultural forms, this trans-historical connection is far more subtle and portable in others. References to pre-20th century racial relations can be found in the overtones of certain political discourses, in the formal characteristics of objects produced by outsider artists, and in the performances of certain Afro-Brazilian rituals, both "secular" and spiritual. This NSF award supported the co-PI's inquiry into this complex and multi-layered realm where historical memory intersects with everyday experiences of cultural expression that have to do with political problems concerning the body: How do the social practices surrounding certain kinds of art offer new frameworks for approaching ideologies of phenotypic difference in the aftermath of world-historical violence grounded in precisely this difference? 

During the funding period, the co-PI spent eighteen months conducting interviews and participant observation among practitioners of different kinds of informal arts (with twelve months of on-site data collection in Brazil and six months of remote research from the United States). Eventually, the co-PI began to focus more on the universe of Afro-Brazilian folk arts in southern Brazil. This was a particularly interesting region in which to study Afro-Brazilian culture, since Afro-Brazilian themes do not feature prominently in popular understandings of this region's history of comparatively recent, predominantly European settlement. Because Afro-Brazilian folk arts are relatively marginalized in this region of Brazil, the co-PI was able to use ethnographic research methodologies to determine how certain kinds of cultural memory survive even when they attempt to be erased by conventional discourses and symbols. In the process, the co-PI was able to provide a different perspective on the Afro-Brazilian arts that is frequently not considered in scientific studies of these expressive cultures, which tend to focus on other regions of Brazil, where the presence of these social forms tend to acquire different contextual meanings.

As a case study for thinking about the insertion of Afro-Brazilian culture into urban informal economies where historical narratives circulate, the co-PI devoted significant amounts of attention to capoeira, an Afro-Brazilian art form that involves elements of dance, combat, musicality, and oral tradition. Because capoeira condenses many themes present in other Afro-Brazilian art forms as well as in popular social and political discourses, the co-PI examined the practices and worldviews of practitioners of this art form. The co-PI trained in the movements and songs of the capoeira repertoire alongside these individuals, accompanied them in their daily lives, and became immersed in the rituals - both mundane and spectacular - through which they develop the mental and bodily capacities required to become a custodian of historical memory. Above all, the co-PI paid attention to how practitioners of capoeira (1) fostered awareness of a traumatized collective history, (2) envisioned human freedom as a practice of aesthetic and political elusiveness, (3) engaged a realm of spirituality and ancestrality derived from traditional Afro-Brazilian cosmologies, and (4) established rapport with the "object-like" qualities of sound in order to uphold rhythm as a central component of selfhood, even outside of capoeira contexts. By examining these dynamics in detail, the researcher documented and analyzed how the transmission and contestation of tradition speaks to the inheritance of historical narratives in the process of constructing complex, overlapping identities and communities in the present day.

The co-PI's dissertation, to be completed in 2023, will make important contributions to anthropology by bringing together research agendas surrounding the topics of media and aesthetics, racialization, and historiography and ethnohistory. It will also intervene in non-academic debates about the operations of ideological systems that can produce socially undesirable outcomes for many different populations in stratified, pluricultural and multi-ethnic societies, particularly in the Americas.
